    a. Fold the bandana in half diagonally.
    b. Center the long edge on your forehead.
    c. Tie the left and right corners together at the back of your head.
    d. Tuck the top corner under the knot.

2. To tie a bandana like a headband: 
    a. Fold the bandana in half diagonally.
    b. Roll the bandana into a long, thin strip.
    c. Place the middle of the strip against your forehead or the nape of your neck.
    d. Bring the ends around to the back of your head and tie into a knot, or tie above your forehead.

3. To tie a bandana around your neck:

2. The opposing player sets their pieces up to mirror your pieces.
3. Roll 2 6-sided dice to start play, and take alternating turns.
4. Move 1 or 2 pieces based on the numbers rolled on the dice, with the option to move 1 piece the total of the 2 numbers or 4 times if the numbers are the same.
5. Do not move a piece to a point occupied by 2 or more of your opponent's pieces, but you can stack your own pieces on a single point.
6. If you move a piece to a point with only 1 of your opponent's pieces, remove that piece from the board and place it on the middle partition.
7. Use at least 1 roll to remove a piece from the partition and start it over from the beginning point on your side of the board.
8. Once all your pieces are in the quadrant closest to the end, begin removing pieces off the board by moving them 1 point past the edge of the board.

1. Split 4 players into 2 teams and deal 13 cards to each player.
2. Arrange cards in ascending or descending order by suit.
3. Starting with the player to the left of the dealer, take turns bidding on the number of tricks and declaring a trump suit.
4. Continue bidding clockwise, with each bid being higher than the previous one in number or suit.
5. Once 3 consecutive players have passed, bidding is closed, and the last player to make a legal bid becomes the winning bidder.
6. The player to the left of the winning bidder plays the first card, then the winning bidder's partner lays their cards face up on the table as the "dummy."
7. The winning bidder selects a card from the dummy's hand, and players take alternating turns playing 1 card from their hand until every player has played a card.
8. Determine the winner of each trick by the highest card in the suit or the highest trump card.
9. Count the number of tricks won by each team to determine the score, modified based on the winning bid.
10. Record points below the line for successfully reaching the opening bid, and above the line for additional tricks or penalties.
11. Continue playing until a team scores 100 points below the line, winning the game, and then play another game to complete the rubber.
12. Calculate the final score by adding points above and below the line, and award 500 points above the line to the winning team that completes the rubber.
